ygData.subject: A new approach to build structure with CPPNs
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi all, Well my project is not finished yet, but here is something that I want to share with the community. It is about using CPPNs to grow physical or

Subject: A new approach to build structure with CPPNs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=bYUF60rc1APX4rZZrwKBR14ZH7F19KtqnZb5L4Y_q3jA1kCMUOAR5nz0iQ

Hi all, 

Well my project is not finished yet, but here is something that I=
 
want to share with the community. It is about using CPPNs to grow 
physic=
al or basically any kind of objects over time. 

The problem involved when =
using a CPPN to describe a material, 
physical objects is this. There is no=
 constraint in the matter that 
is available to build an object. One CPPN c=
an output 100000000000 
parts and another just one. All in the same genome =
complexity. 
Inverted "images" of the CPPN output can lead to infinite buil=
ding of 
parts. And more, most objects may just be too bizzare, like a patt=
ern 
of concentric circles. The search practitioner has to decide and 
deve=
lop too hard things. Like the Alife domain, where you should 
discard indiv=
iduals that do not meet the requirements for something 
that is meanigful. =


The idea I propose is that the phenotype can be built without 
quieriyng =
at each possible coordinate. The CPPN does not have to be a 
snapshot, "pri=
nting" an image on the phenotype surface. 

Consider a 2D grid where you ha=
ve one cell (which I call "the seed") 
at coordinate 0,0. The CPPN is then =
asked what to do with that cell. 
Should it divide, or change type/color/wh=
atever? The CPPN is provided 
with geometric data, of course, that is the c=
oordinates of the 
particular cell that is asked and the time step of devel=
opment time. 
After that, the CPPN is asked again, but for those 2 cells, i=
f the 
first one divides. And then for four. And eight. etc... 

In effect,=
 the CPPN instructs a mass of cells over time (TIME IS RE-
INTRODUCED!) of =
how to develop. A cell divides in this way. If it is 
not completely suroun=
ded by other cells, choose randomly a place 
where to put a new cell. The p=
arent cell still retains its position. 
The CPPN has the input of the curre=
nt cell's position and time until 
end of development. The development of t=
he phenotype happens in 
discrete time steps where all the cells are checke=
d at once and then 
the phenotype is replaced. 

During development time, o=
bjects of cells appear. I can confirm that 
these objects's shapes are dire=
ctly related to the functions used in 
the CPPNs. In fact, when I use sin(x=
) and sin(y) for inputs, they are 
so.. cool! Like flowers and any kind of =
shapes. 

Besides, there are no empty holes, and there is no shit like if y=
ou'd 
try it with the snapshot approach. All objects are just made 
of "mat=
ter". They can be directly moved over a physical simulation or 
something l=
ike this. 

This in fact brings the CPPN theory more closely to engeneering=
 
applications and stuff. Also in Artificial Life. In fact my project 
is d=
edicated to Alife mostly. 

Peter Chervenski
